title: Why do people still argue about world war 2? - Quora

response.answer_text: We study the war. We don’t argue about it per se. We argue about certain points or misconceptions. For example I would argue with a Pearl Harbor conspiracy theorist or the merits of the atomic bombs or the strategy and tactics of a certain campaign, or which weapon or weapon system was better. Its like two sports fans arguing a bout a past Super Bowl or World Series,Besides wit the war,even though it’s over and done with,it’s outcome still effects us to this day.

I cannot answer for others. For myself I seek to look more at the soundness of the political decisions made by various leaders, and the effects on our history. My take is that WWII was a horrible mistake on the part of everyone. I do not even slightly dispute the evil nature of the Nazi, Japanese, Fascist, or Communist regimes. I do however question the effectiveness and soundness of the policies of all the Allied governments, based on the horrific costs of the war, and looking honestly at reasonable cost-benifit estimates of policy decisions made. Take for example the decision by the British & French Governments to not support Czechoslovakia in 1938, where the Czech had a much larger army in proportion to the Germans than the Poles did, and rugged terrain & fortresses, and were a democracy, and a long standing treaty obligation. The problem I see in discussion of this is people making presumptions that I favor the axis, I do not. I am taking a hard and critical look at the decisions made by the Allied leadership.
